text: Kate Bush 50 words for snow Oh buddy hi
my needle drops Anthony Fantan oh here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review Kate Bush 50
words for snow Kate Bush is a UK
singer-songwriter who I needed to get
acclimated with more than I already was
for the purposes of this review full
disclosure here I am not exactly a
scholar when it comes to Kate Bush's
body of work and even though this album
was not clicking with me on my first and
second listens I was up for the
challenge of reviewing the Kate Bush
album especially since her name gets
thrown around with the art pop greats
like Bjork
Peter Gabriel Brian Eno and even though
my first impressions were kind of
lukewarm with this LP it didn't sound
generic to me so I figured it was worth
kind of sticking around and figuring out
why I wasn't totally in love with it but
now with hindsight now that I've heard
it many more times I can understand why
it wasn't clicking with me at first I
can understand why it's it's not
clicking with a lot of people and why it
may not be for every Kate Bush fan and I
think a lot of it has to do with just
just with pacing this album is very slow
Kate's knack for storytelling and her
personality are still here but like I
said they come on slowly the material on
this LP I feel comes on even slower than
what was on 2005 s Ariel really getting
into this LP can be as time-consuming as
just taking an ice cube pulling it out
of the freezer throwing it on the
counter and then just waiting for it to
melt
at room temperature ultra still it's
it's no surprise that in the world of
music there are records that jump out at
you and others that you kind of need to
dive into actively and this is
definitely one of those instances now
the instrumentation on this LP has been
toned down a little bit I think to a
really icy combination of vocals piano
and strings of course there's upright
bass on here and synthesizers and guitar
drums as well and some guest vocalists
but sometimes their appearances the
roles that they play just are so subtle
it's just not going to hit you on first
listen no way but still even the first
time around there's some very obvious
musical posts that that make one track
different from the other the opener
features Kate Bush's son actually
singing and and shockingly his voice is
a lot like hers especially when he's
reaching into those highs he just sings
with this choirboy falsetto and delivers
these these lyrics that are kind of
penned from the narrative of a snowflake
falling to earth and he just gives it so
much innocence and like sincerity which
proves he's as much a singer as he is an
actor kind of like his mother the track
misty has some really nice eruptions of
strings in its center and it's in its
finish line the track Wildman is easily
the most accessible on here has a really
obvious grooves and quirky synthesizers
in there and the chorus just explodes
with the youthfulness of Kate's early
early work snowed in and wheeler Street
is a duet about kind of two lovers who
across time name-dropping very specific
historical events are always kind of
broken up their paths never quite meet
up just run parallel to one another for
all that long
both vocalists on the tracker just so
passionate and they're so sincere I
really love that track it was one of the
tracks that I loved
the very first listen but you made it
even more surprising that the vocalist
guest vocalists on this track is
actually Elton John the title track is a
bit of spoken word with just this groove
this sound an aesthetic that reminds me
of a track or two from the new PJ Harvey
album and on that song you pretty much
get what the title says 50 words and
phrases for snow doled out in a very
dramatic manner by actor and author
Stephen Fry so yeah this is a quiet
album but certainly not uneventful
overall I found the musical elements of
this LP to be pretty nice pretty solid
yeah this thing wanders it meanders it
repeats phrases and ideas to draw them
out in a in a really indulgent display
but it's not like these songs are
without their progression it's just not
obvious progression you've really got to
chew this album over to kind of pick up
all the subtle flavors that are
occurring behind the vocals and the
piano now the other side of the coin
here and this should be no surprise for
Kate pence is the storytelling element
of this album just how prevalent that is
the track Lake Tahoe is about this ghost
woman who's who's calling out to her
dogs she left behind when when she died
I'm gathering and the song misty oddly
enough is about a kind of steamy and
romantic one-night stand with a snowman
literally a snowman and it's only one
night because in the morning he's
nowhere to be found the sheets are all
soaked and they're twigs and leaves left
behind the song wild man is kind of a in
ode to the Yeti lyrically the only
points on this LP that I kind of found
underwhelming where I was really wanting
more were on the title track definitely
where it's pretty much just kate
counting against these different words
and phrases for snow and yeah I really
like the sound of that track I love the
instrumentation I love the feel of that
song but
the more cynical side of me says you
know what this is kind of like a
glorified version of 99 bottles of beer
on the wall and the final tracks
narrative isn't really all that strong
either and just does not feel like it
ties all the ideas of this album
together in a way that I guess I'm happy
with but that's just the lyrics
musically the only song I wasn't really
into on this thing was actually Lake
Tahoe the track storyline gets kind of
mangled and obscured with all these
elongated vocal notes which isn't really
an issue with a lot of the other songs
on this LP plus the melodies on Lake
Tahoe for me just don't feel as as
purposeful don't hit as hard I guess
nearly every other song here I kind of
felt some kind of strong melodic theme
going on but yet Lake Tahoe just kind of
continues to elude me I'm really
enjoying the concept I'm really enjoying
the themes on this thing overall it's
kind of like being trapped in this
winter themed fantasy world created by
Kate for about an hour or maybe rather
lost because this thing in a way is is
kind of like walking into a forest in
the midst of a very heavy snow walking
in too far and kind of losing your place
because the snow is covering your tracks
and now that I have more of a lay of the
land I figured out where things are it's
been a nice experience at every turn
there's another metaphor for death or
love or loss or age and not that I can't
completely relate but I feel like I
would appreciate this album so much more
with a decade or two under my belt
especially since there's a very kind of
strong adult contemporary vibe radiating
off of this thing I just enjoy
personally the quirkier sounds of an
album like The Dreaming more if that
ever changes I know the album to go to
is this thing long-winded is it
indulgent
yes it is so long-winded and indulgent
but that's what kind of makes this thing
stand out and even though yeah it's not
as bold as a lot of Kate's albums it
still ultimately ends up being kind of
idiosyncratic just like her previous
efforts are if you think this thing is
boring I'm not going to tell you you're
missing out on anything because this
album just does not hold what you look
for in music and that's all but if
you're in the search for a very chilly
atmosphere and songs that that kind of
seep into your head very slowly then
this is definitely one of the high
points of this year kind of feeling a
decent too strong seven on this thing
but what do you think of it do you love
it do you hate it why and what do you
think I should review next anthony
Fantana okay Bush fifty words for snow
